message: What is the difference between AngularJS & AJAX ?

data.message: you can try google first before posting in this group.

that was the first result on google :D i didn't get it clearly :) 
i just need two examples showing the difference it would be nice

هي واضحة من التلخيص حتي لو مش عايز تقرأ كل المكتوب 
Angular is a hip JavaScript framework which is made for building large, single-page web applications.

AJAX is a way for JavaScript to request data from a browser without refreshing the page or blocking the application.
AngularJS is a full frontend MVC framework for JavaScript web applications.

why are you confused with them? 
this is like asking what is the difference between php and windows :D

Mostafa Hussein Amr ELsaqqa ana wallahy aret el klam da :D , m3lsh ymkn ana fehmy 3la ady ... ana bas shoft example l todo app using angularJS you can do the same using ajax ? what is special about angularJS (still stupid question) ?
ana lsa mashoftsh da 5als bs shofo ymkn yfedak https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0iQCLlu1dko :D

you can consider it like the difference between using native php and php framework, a well structured platform with new possibilities to code powerful front-end apps with ease

 when you get start with angular JS you will understand the concept about it
think about pure js and jQuery, angular js is another LAYER of abstraction
that means it does not provide new technologies by itself

Vanilla php vs a php framework is a wrong analogy and if he can't wrap his head around ajax then I wouldn't expect him to grasp jquery.

The idea is simple Ahmed Tarek, ignore angularjs for now. Let's take a look at how the web works from a bird's eye view.

You got a web browser, let's say Firefox. You got a web server, somewhere around the world. It's hosting a website, let's call it thewebrocks.tld

Now, Mr. Foobar decided he will visit thewebrocks.com, so he opened his Firefox, typed thewebrocks.tld then... he waited.

.. still waiting

.. he has a slow connection, nothing is showing up yet, he's still waiting

.. now he thinks TEData did the deed, and cut off his Internet.

Aha!! Finally, the website loads.
What happed was Firefox sent a "synchronous" request to the web server that hosts thewebrocks.tld

And it waited for a reply, blocking everything. Showing nothing until the whole thing loads.

Someone at Microsoft in the 90s came up with a brilliant idea (this is a rare occasion in Microsoft, we're grateful) of "asynchronous" requests. That is, to send a request in the background and forget about it.

Until the request is complete, the website (thewebrocks.tld) and the browser are free to do anything else they want.

Hence the name, Ajax = Asynchronous Javascript and xml, aka making browsers suck less.
What happens is, using Javascript you can send asynchronous http requests to a server and then continue whatever else you were doing.

How is this any different than angularjs, jquery, emberjs, knockout, backbonejs, spinejs? There's no relation between them.

Ajax is just a fancy set of technologies to make asynchronous requests less painful, it's a communication model, it's a way through which your client side code would communicate with a server.

Angularjs and the likes are frameworks, a framework is a set of reusable components, libraries and functions that abstract away concepts like data binding, view templates (reusable html bits), server communication, event handling, code organization...etc. 

If after reaching to this line, you still have issues understanding then you're shit outta luck.

Good luck.

It most certainly does, unless you included some resource in your page's head that was blocking the flow, eventually not being able to read the body tag. That was only a simplification of the synchronous communication model, that it happens _now_ and you _actively_ wait for it.

As opposed to it happening in the background and being notified about its status with a callback mechanism of some sort, in the case of asynchronous models.

AJAX is loading some parts of the page in the background, or posting data (if needed) and getting results in the background. 

Browsers give you APIs to do that. Some JS frameworks like jQuery and Angular.JS give you nicer APIs that wrap the browser one, and give you more features in general which differ by framework. 

jQuery for example allows you to get a nicer API for communicating with DOM (HTML elements) in your JS code. Angular.JS gives you an API to handle this communication for you so rhat you don't have to write it at all (in most cases, and keep the code that talks to DOM for the rest of the cases).

When it comes to API both jQuery and Angular.JS have features like intercepting all requests and defereed/promie (a way to chain multiple success/error handlers) , etc. Angular.JS API integrates with the rest of Angular.JS features of course if you prrfer the DOM to be handled for you to have cleaner code.

Google "$.ajax" and "$http" for syntax differences
